http://schema.org/unitCode.description: The unit of measurement given using the UN/CEFACT Common Code (3 characters) or a URL. Other codes than the UN/CEFACT Common Code may be used with a prefix followed by a colon.

http://schema.org/minValue.description: The lower value of some characteristic or property.

http://schema.org/description.description: A short description of the item.

http://schema.org/potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

http://schema.org/additionalProperty.description: A property-value pair representing an additional characteristics of the entitity, e.g. a product feature or another characteristic for which there is no matching property in schema.org. Note: Publishers should be aware that applications designed to use specific schema.org properties (e.g. http://schema.org/width, http://schema.org/color, http://schema.org/gtin13, ...) will typically expect such data to be provided using those properties, rather than using the generic property/value mechanism.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/valueReference.description: A pointer to a secondary value that provides additional information on the original value, e.g. a reference temperature.

http://schema.org/value.description: The value of the quantitative value or property value node. For QuantitativeValue, the recommended type for values is 'Number'. For PropertyValue, it can be 'Text;', 'Number', 'Boolean', or 'StructuredValue'.

http://schema.org/additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

http://schema.org/maxValue.description: The upper value of some characteristic or property.

http://schema.org/unitText.description: A string or text indicating the unit of measurement. Useful if you cannot provide a standard unit code forunitCode.

http://schema.org/image.description: An image of the item. This can be a URL or a fully described ImageObject.

http://schema.org/description.description: A short description of the item.

http://schema.org/potentialAction.description: Indicates a potential Action, which describes an idealized action in which this thing would play an 'object' role.

http://schema.org/mainEntityOfPage.description: Indicates a page (or other CreativeWork) for which this thing is the main entity being described. See background notes for details. Inverse property: mainEntity.

http://schema.org/additionalType.description: An additional type for the item, typically used for adding more specific types from external vocabularies in microdata syntax. This is a relationship between something and a class that the thing is in. In RDFa syntax, it is better to use the native RDFa syntax - the 'typeof' attribute - for multiple types. Schema.org tools may have only weaker understanding of extra types, in particular those defined externally.

http://schema.org/sameAs.description: URL of a reference Web page that unambiguously indicates the item's identity. E.g. the URL of the item's Wikipedia page, Freebase page, or official website.

description: A point value or interval for product characteristics and other purposes.

http://schema.org/numberOfPlayers.description: Indicate how many people can play this game (minimum, maximum, or range).

http://schema.org/fuelEfficiency.description: The distance traveled per unit of fuel used; most commonly miles per gallon (mpg) or kilometers per liter (km/L).Note 1: There are unfortunately no standard unit codes for miles per gallon or kilometers per liter.Use unitText to indicate the unit of measurement, e.g. mpg or km/L.Note 2: There are two ways of indicating the fuel consumption, fuelConsumption (e.g. 8 liters per 100 km) and fuelEfficiency (e.g. 30 miles per gallon). They are reciprocal.Note 3: Often, the absolute value is useful only when related to driving speed ("at 80 km/h") or usage pattern ("city traffic"). You can use valueReference to link the value for the fuel economy to another value.

http://schema.org/fuelConsumption.description: The amount of fuel consumed for traveling a particular distance or temporal duration with the given vehicle (e.g. liters per 100 km).Note 1: There are unfortunately no standard unit codes for liters per 100 km.Use unitText to indicate the unit of measurement, e.g. L/100 km.Note 2: There are two ways of indicating the fuel consumption, fuelConsumption (e.g. 8 liters per 100 km) and fuelEfficiency (e.g. 30 miles per gallon). They are reciprocal.Note 3: Often, the absolute value is useful only when related to driving speed ("at 80 km/h") or usage pattern ("city traffic"). You can use valueReference to link the value for the fuel consumption to another value.

http://schema.org/eligibleDuration.description: The duration for which the given offer is valid.

http://schema.org/numberOfPreviousOwners.description: The number of owners of the vehicle, including the current one.Typical unit code(s): C62

http://schema.org/numberOfForwardGears.description: The total number of forward gears available for the transmission system of the vehicle.Typical unit code(s): C62

http://schema.org/valueReference.description: A pointer to a secondary value that provides additional information on the original value, e.g. a reference temperature.

http://schema.org/numAdults.description: The number of adults staying in the unit.

http://schema.org/durationOfWarranty.description: The duration of the warranty promise. Common unitCode values are ANN for year, MON for months, or DAY for days.

http://schema.org/yearlyRevenue.description: The size of the business in annual revenue.

http://schema.org/numberOfDoors.description: The number of doors.Typical unit code(s): C62

http://schema.org/numberOfAxles.description: The number of axles.Typical unit code(s): C62

http://schema.org/numChildren.description: The number of children staying in the unit.

http://schema.org/weight.description: The weight of the product or person.

http://schema.org/mileageFromOdometer.description: The total distance travelled by the particular vehicle since its initial production, as read from its odometer.Typical unit code(s): KMT for kilometers, SMI for statute miles

http://schema.org/inventoryLevel.description: The current approximate inventory level for the item or items.

http://schema.org/cargoVolume.description: The available volume for cargo or luggage. For automobiles, this is usually the trunk volume.Typical unit code(s): LTR for liters, FTQ for cubic foot/feetNote: You can use minValue and maxValue to indicate ranges.

http://schema.org/vehicleSeatingCapacity.description: The number of passengers that can be seated in the vehicle, both in terms of the physical space available, and in terms of limitations set by law.Typical unit code(s): C62 for persons

http://schema.org/eligibleQuantity.description: The interval and unit of measurement of ordering quantities for which the offer or price specification is valid. This allows e.g. specifying that a certain freight charge is valid only for a certain quantity.

http://schema.org/partySize.description: Number of people the reservation should accommodate.

http://schema.org/advanceBookingRequirem.description: The amount of time that is required between accepting the offer and the actual usage of the resource or service.

http://schema.org/deliveryLeadTime.description: The typical delay between the receipt of the order and the goods leaving the warehouse.

http://schema.org/numberOfEmployees.description: The number of employees in an organization e.g. business.

title: QuantitativeValue
